Subject: RE: [junit] Categories in JUnit 4.8
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=212099090; y=D3TgV6QYKkpMCqEhHLlSjFMPkfaoEeTa1tySNjYed5eRs_0lgnk

Hi, 

> > My take on using strings as markers are that this will 
> faile over time.
> >
> Well, TestNG has been using string groups for more than five 
> years now and nobody has complained, so I don't think it's 
> really failing.  I don't even remember anyone suggesting to 
> use statically typed groups either (if ever), so there 
> doesn't seem to really be a problem there.

Well, since we're enriching the discussion with input from our
favorite projects, I'll follow suit. :-)

NUnit has used string categories for a long time without serious
problems. Two minor problems have come up, which one might want
to keep in mind:

1) Some folks would prefer to use enumerations, for reasons
of type safety. To support this, CategoryAttribute has
a protected constructor that allows folks to create
a derived attribute (e.g. FastAttribute) that sets the
internal string category to whatever is wanted. Ultimately,
since categories are used in the command line, we need
a string anyway.

2) We support category expressions on the command line,
using a limited operator syntax. Unfortunately, the
operators include '-' which many people tend to use in
their category identifiers. This leads to situations where
the category specification appears to be ignored. If
I were starting over, I would use space-delimited 
key words, that is...
  "fast and not database"
rather than...
  "fast-database"

Differences in how attributes are defined and used in
Java and C# mean that the above is probably not directly 
useful, but it may lead to some further ideas.
 
Charlie
